item.title: Xbox confirms five games leaving Game Pass in early November
item.content:encoded:
Stalker 2: Heart of Chornobyl! Frostpunk! More!

Microsoft has revealed the next batch of titles set to leave its Game Pass subscription service.

Come 15th November, the following the following titles will be removed from Game Pass:

  • Football Manager 24
  • Spirittea
  • Stalker 2: Heart of Chornobyl
  • Blacksmith Master (Game Preview)
  • Frostpunk

If you are interested in any of the above games, now is your last chance to play them via Game Pass (at least for now, they may well be re-added at a later date).

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

There are some notable titles here, including Frostpunk. "A thrilling but thin survival twist on the city builder genre, oozing dark charisma and political dilemmas," reads Eurogamer's Frostpunk review from 2018.

Stalker 2, meanwhile, only made its debut on the service last year, when the game was released on Xbox and PC following a rather tumultuous period for developer GSC Game World. Stalker 2 was delayed several times due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The studio relocated staff to safely finish the project elsewhere, while others joined Ukraine's armed forces, and it also dealt with Russian hackers who leaked test builds. GSC went on to release a documentary detailing Stalker 2's particularly difficult development.

Heart of Chornobyl "stays faithful to the open world survival shooter of yesteryear," reads Eurogamer's Stalker 2 review.

For everything else in Microsoft's subscription service, you can check out our handy Xbox Game Pass guide detailing the many titles available.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/xbox-confirms-five-games-leaving-game-pass-in-early-november

item.title: Battlefield 6 maps are smaller compared to the rest of the series, community discovers
item.content:encoded:
A member of the Battlefield community has made a visual and graphical comparison of Battlefield 6's maps with the rest of the series, showing the latest release's maps are smaller than prior entries.

User ClaraTheRed posted their findings on the Battlefield Reddit, which included a size map of all 87 maps across the games, as well a graphical breakdown of both total and playable area across those maps. In doing so, it's been made clear that the vast majority of maps fall on the smaller side of the graph.

Operation Firestorm - currently the largest map in the game and itself a port from Battlefield 3 - is ranked 32nd overall across the series in terms of playable space. The original Operation Firestorm from Battlefield 3 is far larger, ranking 7th. Though this is largely down to the perimeter of the map being brought in rather than any shrinkage that would impact the gameplay too much.

In terms of original maps, Mirak Valley is the largest among Battlefield 6's arsenal, ranking 35th. The rest are sprinkled throughout the rankings, with the smallest Battlefield 6 map Saints Quarter standing proud as the 2nd smallest map in the series history.

It is worth noting that a handful of those larger maps are DLC maps, and the comparison between BF6 and previous games does place finished games against a relatively new one with years left of post-launch support left to go. Many of the Battlefield 3: Armoured Kill DLC maps rank among the highest, which skew the chart somewhat due to their bolder vehicle-focused scope.

So why do people care about this? Well, there's a community sentiment brewing around the size of Battlefield 6's maps and how the game hasn't felt as big as previous titles. While these graphs do lend some credence to the idea, further discussion in the thread noted that shape and structure of the maps tend to make them feel smaller. For example, Siege of Cairo's many alleyways and corridors feel quite compact.

It's an interesting debate! Let us know how you feel about the map sizes below! If you've not had a chance to check out the game yourself, why not read Eurogamer's review to get a glimpse of what's in store. Right now, players are diving into the new Redsec Battle Royale mode, and coming away with mixed thoughts.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/battlefield-6-maps-are-smaller-compared-to-the-rest-of-the-series-community-discovers

item.title: There's apparently a very good Mario-themed reason you should go and see Wicked: For Good this November
item.content:encoded:
If you are planning on clicking your heels together and setting off to the cinema to watch Wicked: For Good, the next film in the musical adaptation of Oz's witches Glinda and Elphaba, you may also get a first proper peep at another famous duo.

According to insider accounts @MyTimeToShineH and @TheWickedSource, a trailer for The Super Mario Galaxy Movie - which is to say, the upcoming sequel to 2023's hugely successful The Super Mario Bros. Movie - will be attached to screenings of Wicked: For Good, which is set to release on 21st November.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The Mario movie sequel was first teased for a 2026 release back in March of last year. At this time, we were told the next film in the franchise will "broaden Mario's world further", though further details were kept largely under wraps. Following this, Toad voice actor Keegan-Michael Key teased the film would feature an "intriguing" setting alongside "old favourite" characters and "really deep cuts", but again stopped short of revealing too much.

Then, just this September, Nintendo gave us a better idea of just how much broader this film's setting will be, when it announced the official title as The Super Mario Galaxy Movie. Perhaps later this month we will get a look at Rosalina, who surely will make an appearance in the film. I mean, Lumalee popped up in the first Mario Bros. film, so was this all a bit of foreshadowing? Well, there's potentially not much longer until we find out, with some now hoping Ariana Grande will voice Rosalina.

Along with a Mario sequel, Nintendo also has a live-action Legend of Zelda film in the works. Earlier this year, the studio announced Link and Zelda will be played by Benjamin Evan Ainsworth and Bo Bragason.

For more on the upcoming Zelda film, be sure to check out Christian Donlan's feature: Does Link's human face in the Zelda movie make anyone else feel a little... odd?

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/theres-apparently-a-very-good-mario-themed-reason-you-should-go-and-see-wicked-for-good-this-november
